title: The precarious path of e-cig startup Juul: From Silicon Valley darling to $38 billion behemoth under criminal investigation
text:
E-cigarette company Juul faces an uncertain future.

The $38 billion company has staked a precarious path into the limelight, starting out as glitzy gadget and eventually billing itself as something resembling a public health tool.

A decade after launching its original devices, called the Ploom, with a party in San Francisco's trendy Mission District, the company landed a $12.8 billion investment from Marlboro maker Altria.

In between, the company rebranded three times, hosted another launch party in New York City, sold some of its assets to Japan Tobacco International, and attracted a series of non-traditional backers that range from a marijuana therapeutics company to several hedge funds. One investor quietly sold its stake in the company to two other firms, according to PitchBook.

Now, Juul faces challenges that include a warning from the US Food and Drug Administration, probes by members of congress, and several state- and country-wide bans, as well as renewed questions about its products' long term health impacts.
